svg.content: <mxfile host="Electron" modified="2020-03-28T14:23:26.334Z" agent="Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_12_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) draw.io/12.6.5 Chrome/80.0.3987.86 Electron/8.0.0 Safari/537.36" etag="D4hjUQtuS_Kwy9j05ghZ" version="12.6.5" type="device"><diagram id="58tsdZ0BhqN9uodqgCVt" name="Page-1"></diagram></mxfile>

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 49px; margin-left: 1px;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Incentive Shapes
Incentives can be calculated from a system structure. Some sub-systems, attributes, or components, like certain angles or corners, would create forces pushing any objects to gather at those points.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 469px; margin-left: 1px;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Other incentives can take the form of:
- shape/boundary completion (more stable as a closed shape than as a set of components, so the incentive is to create closed shapes)
- avoiding limits (unrestricted growth in whichever directions are not restricted)
- intent alignments (using components with similar or complementary goals to achieve intents easier than building those components)
- efficiencies (low cost states/moves/structures)

switch.text: Other incentives can take the form of:...

a.text: Viewer does not support full SVG 1.1
